A lot of HR people have slandered me for saying that most often than not, bad HR practice is only a symptom of the problem, and the real problem is bad leadership. An organization cannot and will not get more value than they expect from and permit their HR unit to deliver.

A company with great leadership will set high ethical and professional standards for their HR and recruit the type of HR professional that can help attain these standards, else they train or replace them. 

In a nutshell, the solution provided by HR reflects what leadership expects of them.

In this days of digital disruption, there are hardly anyone who stops work at work, you still tend to send report, reply mails and take official calls after work hours and on weekends. In order words, traditional work arrangement doesn't respect the official work hours, so i won't expect otherwise in remote work arrangement. 

As a matter of fact, i believe where possible, while establishing an official work hour on paper, remote work should allow for more flexible work structure and timing. Some people are usually more productive at certain times, so if their work doesn't require them to be at their desk at a certain time, then judge them on their productivity and performance and not time they choose to work.

You raised a number of great points here and I also love your advise to mentees to kind of give back and appreciate their mentors as much as they possibly can.

However, I do not quite agree with the ‚ÄúUse and Dump phrase‚Äù 

Mentorship is a noble role for the mentor and voluntary relationship for both. They both are trying to satisfy a need, and are absolutely free to diplomatically disconnect from the relationship anytime they deem fit, most especially when the purpose of the relationship has been met with no hard feelings on the part of any.  

Saying the mentor has been used somehow makes it feels like the mentor is expectant of a reward or feels entitled to the mentee. 

As a mentor, if you are discouraged about mentoring others because previous mentees disconnected after you had helped them achieve their goals, then you need to check what your driving forces are or your self esteem or both. 

Note: I maintain very good relationship with my mentors, that‚Äôs my personal style. But not every one would do that, not every of my mentee does that, and I have no issues.

This is the reason why maltreated employees don't come out to lay their complaints. The average Nigerian have given up on the Judiciary as the last hope for the common man, social media has since been their only hope to express their grievance and maybe get justice.

The allegations against them weren't made by faceless people, they came from former employees who are courageous enough to call them out without hiding their identities.

In my opinion, i think business and HR leaders needs to see talent mobility as an inherent risk associated with the doing business - the same way they experience and confront risk associated with change in demand and global economic disruption. 

Let‚Äôs look at it this way, a brand can spend millions of Dollars developing a product/service only to release the product to find out their competition has or is about to launch an advanced version of their product or service.  What they simply do is rejig their R&D team for another round of innovation.

Similarly, in spite of the revenue allotted to employee experience and engagement, companies should plan for the risk of their imminent departure, even sooner than predicted.

Nice topic. Employee retention is actually relative. It isn‚Äôt always a positive thing. If you carry out an engagement and employee utilization survey on this civil servants,¬† their high retention would defile modern HR logic.
 
I think the question should be where are the civil service and the Nigerian system getting it wrong. 

Let me share some reasons with you. 1. Little job mobility within the civil service
2, Public-private job migration is almost non-existent.
3. High rate of unemployment.

Only engagement driven retention is worth reckoning with.

To butress your third point, I do tell people that HR is in the business of influence and persuasion. It needs to make the line managers understand and appreciate that  they are HR on the line to their people, and anytime their employee need to see HR is an indication of lapses in their leadership.

This is a feat. Sterling Bank is putting to shame the perception that work life balance is the alternatives forgone for working in a Bank and interestingly doing so when their counterparts prides in their toxic style they label "Fast Paced Environment" 

They are also changing the narrative that you don't have to work for a Multi-national before you see culture actually manifest in people's lives for a better employee experience.

What would you have expected the candidate to do, stand in the rain or go back to his house?


Does that mean he will be a better candidate than others who didn‚Äôt get wet because they have a personal?

That he didn‚Äôt call to inform the interviewer that he is running late says a lot about the candidates‚Äô professionalism, he could miss an appointment with your biggest clients without giving notice.

I agree to value based recruitment and flexibly of selection criteria, but note that potential value should be ascertained using Objective and VALID measurement yardstick not emotions.

Every interviewer should have a clear picture of the ideal candidate in mind, this help reduce Halo and Primacy effect!

Ezekiel, well,  I understand it hurts to know most recruiter don't read cover letters and spend an average of 6-30 seconds to read a resume. Firstly if job requirements says it wants someone with 5 years experience in a FMCG, a candidate that didn't meet this requirement(s) stand no chance of been considered however good the cover letter is, so it might be wise to leave out cover letters and check what you looking for in resumes. Secondly, yes you can decide if a resume is successful within few seconds, you just need to spot key points to decide if this CV will pass except you aren't sure of your person specification.
Queeneth Duru you have a point, but when that recruitment is a time based deliverable, you wouldn't fancy reading cover letters of 500 or more CVs

Andrew Bourne every job has a person specification that can't be determined my the cover letter, only the CV except in rare cases where the writing skills/ understanding of the role is a major KPI of the Job. In which case the person's CV/ profile will be the final decider

I don't agree with you. Some people are introverted and would want to reveal as little as possible about their career on social media, that does not make them less of a professional. It might be fallacious to access candidates based on their Linkedin profiles alone.

This is a nice write up.

I am at a loss on how summarize my story with regards to internet. 

For Linkedin; a platform many of my ally (Fresh Graduates) refused to join because they felt it is meant for only professionals, gave me my first job shortly after joining and has set me on a career path of my dream. 

Some of the information and knowledge I have acquired on Linkedin are ones i may not acquire in a two years professional experience. 

Most Importantly for me and i quote you "It (Linkedin) allows me to see what my old colleagues are up in their careers" I get mentor-ship from older colleagues even without their notice just by seeing their career summary & movement, academic background & qualification, job descriptions & achievement amongst other things. This gives me a clearer picture of where i am headed and reinforces my desire to achieve much more than they did.

To answer your question, in that case, i will hold the maintenance agency responsible.

I will also ask you a question that drives me closer to my point. Who would you hold responsible if a moving car splashes dirty rain water on you? The driver of the car or road Maintenance Agency? I can imagine what your answer will be.

My point is this: aside bad road which is beyond the control of car owners, there are other factors that makes a car road unworthy that are within the control of car owner.

I am therefore saying that all road unworthy cars should not use the excuse of bad road as a justification to operate.
Two wrongs makes no right!

A very realistic write up, need i say that very many people especially in Nigeria faces several "Job satisfaction" related problem.   

I will explain by using this quote "The two most important days in your life are the day you are born and the day you find out why" -Mark Twain.

Everybody has a talent, unique purpose and a calling, it is sometimes difficult to decipher this purpose but i have found out from the track record of great people that the only way to be SUSTAINABLY fulfilled and satisfied is to discover your purpose, engage in and build a career around it, money and other material benefits in your job will only bring satisfaction that can't stand the test of time. That is, it might be difficult if not impossible to get more from your job if that job isn't aligned with your purpose.  

I suggest the best solution is to discover your purpose, which will help you to redefine your career path, Ask yourself this basic question:  

1. What do i enjoy doing? 
2. What do i do without getting tired? 
3. What are the things i can do even without getting a pay? 
4. What do i do so well that everybody commends?  

However, in the process of changing your current job or career for a career that is aligned to your purpose or interest you might not get the expected financial incentive at first, (passion drives you during this period) but eventually money will come.
